TITLE.P: Voluntary Transparancy Notice ‘Dilution refrigerator’ Scalable Quantum Photonics Lab 10749

SHORT_DESCR.P: To build the next quantum internet or to achieve quantum computing advantage, the systems we build need to be scalable. In the SQP Lab, we develop scalable quantum technology by combining photonics with solid-state spins into semiconductor foundry processes. To achieve this goal, we engineer large-scale quantum-compatible integrated photonics and study solid state spins in diamond and silicon.

A future quantum internet will connect (quantum) computers all over the world. It will enable to send and receive information using quantum bits (qubits) that follow the rules of quantum mechanics. In the Quantum Internet division, our goal is to develop technologies to enable quantum communication between any two places on earth. For this radically new technology several major new and potentially game-changing applications have already been identified. One such application is to provide a fundamentally secure way of communication, in which privacy is guaranteed by the laws of physics. Also, quantum processors can be connected into a quantum network in order to assemble a large quantum computing cluster. This approach is called networked quantum computing and offers a natural path towards scalability, complementary to the quantum computing work. Combining a quantum internet and a networked quantum computer allows remote users/providers to perform secure quantum computing ‘in the cloud’.

To build the next quantum internet or to achieve quantum computing advantage, the systems we build need to be scalable. In the SQP Lab, we develop scalable quantum technology by combining photonics with solid-state spins into semiconductor foundry processes. To achieve this goal, we engineer large-scale quantum-compatible integrated photonics and study solid state spins in diamond and silicon.

The operation temperatures required for the spin systems studied in our lab are in the 100 mK range, and so the group needs a dilution refrigerator to conduct its experiments. Due to the worldwide Helium shortage, the group wants to purchase a dry dilution refrigerator.

D_JUSTIFICATION.P: The Scalable Quantum Photonics lab develops large-scale cryogenic photonics with integrated color centers and single-photon detectors. A number of color centers that the lab will work with, such as the SiV in diamond, require temperatures below 100 mK to maintain long coherence times. The group will rely on a dilution cryostat with a photonic probe station to conduct its experiments. Due to the worldwide Helium shortage, the group is planning to purchase a dry dilution refrigerator.
Other than the operation temperatures, the main requirements are cooldown times

Many components (Nanopositioner stages, internal optics and mounts, PCBs, filters, cold fingers) are homemade and optimized for the experiments. Significant time and cost investments have been invested in designing and setting up optical paths, mounts, and optics. Furthermore, the lab will have joint experiments with other researchers at Delft, resulting in a significant number of compatible setups. Deviating from this would result in a substantial delay in the research and may prevent further progress. In addition, the developments of these components are made for the existing setups, and developing new components and operating under different circumstances will impact the viability of comparing research results due to differences in performance. Finally, it is crucial to guarantee the flexibility to switch between components of a fridge. For example, to be able to change the nanopositioners, optics, mounts, cold fingers, and filters without the overhead or making compromises to the experiment.

It is the Universities belief, that Bluefors Oy is the only supplier that offers the unique combination of required specifications and additional needs/benefits of/for the university, which are necessary for the successful continuation of the research at the Scalable Quantum Photonics Lab at Qutech. The TU Delft intends to award the contract for the replacement refrigerator by the purchase of a Dilution refrigerator to Bluefors Oy.

The goal of this voluntary transparency notice is to inform the market that TU Delft intends to start a Negotiation Procedure without prior notice on the bases of technical uniqueness and therefore lack of competition. Based on market research, it appears that Bluefors Oy, is the only appropriate supplier on the market that can meet the technical specifications. It has been unequivocally established that there is no competition for this purchase for technical reasons.

The contracting authority will observe a standstill period of at least 20 (twenty) calendar days starting after the date of publishing this announcement (6th of January 2023 until 27th of January 2023).

Any supplier who disagrees with this decision may appeal against it within the aforementioned period in preliminary relief proceedings before the Preliminary Relief Court in The Hague. After this standstill period, rights to object expire.
